title: Update TLS cipher suites
body:
* Use ANSSI recommendation
* Use secure and recommended TLS cipher suites from https://ciphersuite.info/cs/?security=secure

Signed-off-by: Florentin Dubois <florentin.dubois@clever-cloud.com>

title: Update dependencies and apply linter suggestions
body: Signed-off-by: Florentin Dubois <florentin.dubois@clever-cloud.com>

title: Addresses part of #808 and #810
body:
Changes for #808:
- inlined `SessionManager::close_session`
- make sure the SessionManager is not already borrowed when calling `ProxySession::close`

Changes for #810:
- removed Soft and Hard stops error logs
- the sessions slab is cloned to iterate over without retaining the borrow_mut lock
- shutting down session was deleting the back entry in the session manager but not the front entry, so a worker couldn't empty its sessions slab. `ProxySession::shutdown` is now responsible for removing its front entry
- back and front buffers set to `None` are considered empty so new and reset sessions properly shutdown
- tcp sessions that try to connect to a backend with an invalid accept token return `ConnectionError::HostNotFound` instead of crashing

Signed-off-by: Eloi DEMOLIS <eloi.demolis@clever-cloud.com>

title: Lifetime of a session doc
body: To fulfill issue #689 we want to document how sessions are created and how they live/die.

title: 0.14 trickle errors in lib
body:
As in #807 we want to avoid panics in form of `expect` statements in higher level functions of the Sōzu lib: proxy creation and start.

This PR changes the signature of these function to return a Result that will be handled by binaries.

title: 0.14 error management
body:
A big part of Sōzu performs the Success/Failure logic using Option instead of Result. There are still too many `expect` and `unwrap` statements.

This PR aims at removing `expect` and `unwrap` statements, or at least convert `unwrap`s into more verbose `expect("some message")`.

This changes some function signatures to return `anyhow::Result<Struct>` instead of `Option<Struct>` or `Result<Struct, String>`.

This adds a lot of comments about errors we should trickle up, and `panic!` or `unwrap` or `expect` statement that are never called but could crash Sōzu. It is good practice to avoid those statements. Trickling up errors is better.

title: 0.14 include the worker id in the in_flight hashmap
body:
In order to better retrieve the worker id when receiving a response from a worker, it has been suggested to add a worker id field to the `Server` and `Proxy` structs of the sozu library:

- #798

After trying to extend the `RequestIdentifier` into a `RequestSummary` that would be written in the in_flight hash map, we realized the worker loop does know a worker's id when receiving from it, and can pretty conveniently pipe it together with the response for further handling.

This PR remove unelegant parsing of a request id to find the worker id within it.

This does NOT close #798 however, which is still a discussion to be had.

Also: a lot of variable renaming, mostly 

- `worker_id` and `client_id` and variants such as `new_worker_id`.
- ProxyRequestData => ProxyRequestOrder
- ProxyResponseData => ProxyResponseContent

title: 0.14 http499
body:
Tackling the issue

- #767

we found inconsistencies in variable names around request parsing.
We may still introduce the 499 status code handling, but this should be merged anyway.

title: Fix main process upgrade and shutdown
body:
As explained in

- #795 

Upgrading sozu would crash after a few upgrades. The reason is because of this PR

- #742 

which prevented the main process to actually shut down leading in all sorts of chaotic behaviors. Also

- #743 

made the CTL try to upgrade the workers from the old main instead of the new one after upgrading the main process.

title: 0.14 refactor status command
body:
The status querying logic, as of now, works like so:

1. the CLI asks for a list of workers
2. the CLI queries each worker individually (through the main process)

This PR aims at putting the whole logic into the main process, so that:

1. the CLI asks the main process for the status
2. the main process queries all workers individually
3. the status is sent to the CLI

title: fix the upgrade
body:
Calling `upgrade` in the CLI several times over yields this repeating error in a loop:

```
2022-09-02T10:50:44.204278Z 1662115844204278295 0 SOZU ERROR	could not parse listeners list (from fd 15): Error("EOF while parsing a value", line: 1, column: 0)
2022-09-02T10:50:44.304522Z 1662115844304522941 17819 MAIN INFO	waiting for scm sockets
2022-09-02T10:50:44.204278Z 1662115844204278295 0 SOZU ERROR	could not parse listeners list (from fd 15): Error("EOF while parsing a value", line: 1, column: 0)
2022-09-02T10:50:44.304522Z 1662115844304522941 17819 MAIN INFO	waiting for scm sockets
```

This branch refactors the error propagation and aims at solving this bug.

title: 0.14 cli table formatting
body: solves #788

title: input path rule in config.toml and the CLI
body:
Up until now the proxy logic of Sōzu did enforce a PathRule when accepting requests on a frontend:

```rust
/// A filter for the path of incoming requests
#[derive(Debug, Clone, PartialEq, Eq, Hash, PartialOrd, Ord, Serialize, Deserialize)]
#[serde(rename_all = "SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE")]
pub enum PathRule {
    /// filters paths that start with a pattern, typically "/api"
    Prefix(String),
    /// filters paths that match a regex pattern
    Regex(String),
    /// filters paths that exactly match a pattern, no more, no less
    Equals(String),
}
```

(comments added in this PR)

but it would only effectively apply the Prefix path rule, that was applied by default.

This PR ensures this path rule can be input in the `config.toml`:

```toml
frontends = [
  { address = "0.0.0.0:8080", hostname = "lolcatho.st", tags = { key = "value" }, path = "/[a-z]{3}", path_type = "REGEX" },
]
```

And in the command line

```
sozu --config config.toml frontend http add --address 0.0.0.0:8080 --hostname lolcatho.st  --path-equals api id MyCluster
```


This should please @miton18 I've been told.

title: gather and display main process metrics
body:
As a continuation to

- #783 
- #791 

We need to restore the display of the main process metrics next to the worker metrics, as in the 0.13.6 version, of the form:

```
MAIN PROCESS
============
┌─────────────────────────┬───────┬───────┐
│                         │ gauge │ count │
├─────────────────────────┼───────┼───────┤
│ configuration.backends  │ 3     │       │
├─────────────────────────┼───────┼───────┤
│ configuration.clusters  │ 2     │       │
├─────────────────────────┼───────┼───────┤
│ configuration.frontends │ 3     │       │
└─────────────────────────┴───────┴───────┘
```

title: store cluster metrics in a simpler way, query them all
body:
Continuation of #783 

This pull request removes what @Geal started to work on but didn't finish.
The cluster metrics are now stored without timestamps, which reduces
the strain on the memory and thus is cleared only everyday at midgnight.
They are stored in a simple binary tree map of the form
`cluster_or_backend_id -> (key, value)`

The relation between is clusters and backend is tracked in another map of the form `backend_id -> cluster_id `

This pull request removes the option to enable the timed collection of metrics.

## to do
- [x] queries for cluster and backend metrics, providing their ids and metric names.
- [x] error management on cluster & backend ids provided by the CLI
- [x] error management alltogether

solves #790  #789

title: Rename "application" to "cluster"
body:
As a follow-up to issue #626 and for a better consistency, we need to remove the word "application" from Sōzu entirely, and finish to replace it with the more fitting "cluster".

A cluster is a set of:
- frontends (IP:port addresses, not to be confused with web apps)
- routing rules
- backends

Since the backends are usually identical instances of a same piece of software, the whole cluster may be designated as an "application" by a system administrator who would use Sōzu to redirect traffic to several instances of a same software, or "application". This, however, is a user-centric denomination and does not fit the naming framework of a reverse proxy.

"Cluster" is still a bit misleading, but is better nonetheless.

## Todo

- [x] rename all "application" (incl. structs & enums containing _app_ in their name)
- [x] write a bit of documentation to explain what a cluster is

title: Update command, lib and binaries dependencies
add a custom-tag field to all front-ends
body:
solves #756 

We want to attach custom tags to all sorts of frontends: HTTP, HTTPS, TCP in order to better retrieve them in the access logs.

There are roughly four steps in doing so, as described by @FlorentinDUBOIS:

- [x] adding the `custom_tag` field to all front-end definitions, to the command line interface, etc
- [x] retrieving the custom tags in the big server loop
- [x] inject them in the `Session` structure
- [x] pass them to the underlying `Http<Front>` wich creates the access logs with the `info_access!` macro

While diving into this issue:

- #718 

I could not reproduce the problematic immediate return & improper shutdown.

But I found unclear code in the `CommandServer::worker_order()` function, so I:

Without this, sozu throws an error when trying to add a certificate using sozuctl.

title: Fix documentation
body:
This PR contains a fix for the `bin/config.toml` file.

As a young user of Sozu, I make this small contribution to sozu's documentation with this little fix.
Nothing else to add except that the Sozu's documentation is really clear and complete!

title: comments on the worker and client loops, renamed variables
body: A very minor rewording and explaining of what happens in the worker loop and client loops

title: sort use statements in files of main process
body:
#749 was a good idea, but some files were forgotten, those of `/bin`, Sōzu's main process. Their use statements were already compacted but not sorted.

The sorting order of use statements:

1. std/core `use std::str::String;`
2. extern crates, `use rand::thread_rng`
3. other workspaces, `use sozu_command_lib::command::CommandRequest;`
4. this crate, `use crate::cli::MetricsCmd`

Separated by an empty line. `rustfmt` then orders each group alphabetically.

title: Format all use statements
body:
In a ongoing quest for consistency, here is a thorough and opiniated formatting of all `use` statements in Sōzu, following principles [found here](https://github.com/rust-lang/rustfmt/issues/4107), that is **from the furthest dependencies to the closest**:

- std
- external crates
- workspace crates (sozu command lib…)
- the actual module (`self`, `super`)

title: Simple refactor of ctl
body:
In order to better work on so many issues with the command line, a simple restructuring of the code seems appropriate, to ward off this main problem:

- The file `command.rs` contains too much logic! Creation and  sending of `CommandRequest`s, the handling of responses, the display of result, the certificate logic… => **1800 lines** of too much diversity
- the pattern matching of command line arguments takes up too much space in `mod.rs` and renders the code unworkable. Destructuring all variables and reinjecting them into called functions is a waste of space.

The solution is to:

- create two additionnal files, one for the printing logic, `display.rs`, and one for the creation of `CommandRequest`, `request_builder.rs`
- refactor the destructuring of command line arguments in `request_builder.rs` to save space in `mod.rs`

The result of this refactoring:

- `mod.rs` shrinks from 320 lines to 156
- `command.rs` shrinks from 1800 lines to 980
- 100 lines suppressed alltogether

Most importantly: **each file handles a distinct type of logic** now.

title: 0.14 fix state parsing
body:
In order to solve this issue:

-  #744 

Let's create a generic command parser in the command lib, with:

- tests,
- generic types, 
- error propagation
- readable syntax


closes #744

title: Simple refactoring of ctl
body:
Instead of passing `channel` and `timeout` dozens of times as arguments, put them in a `CommandManager` struct and put all the logic into `impl CommandManager` blocks.

This refactoring deletes 150 lines of code and will allow further refactoring down the line, notably the solving of 

- #740

title: Make the command server entirely event based
body:
Digging into #708 proved difficult because the code of the Command Server lacked a proper refactoring.

This PR renders the event-based nature of the Command Server systematic.

### Replacement of `answer_error()` and `answer_success()`

These functions answered directly to the client. Their use within the code was boiler plate. They are replaced by `return_error()` and `return_success()`, who send a `CommandMessage::Advancement` (new variant) to the command server, using his `command_tx`.

The command server, in turn, calls `notify_advancement_to_client()`, that does what `answer_error()` and `answer_success()` did.

### New enums!

A good-for-all `Success` to be returned either by `Result<Success>` or on a channel. Satisfies `std::fmt::Display` for logging and responding to the client.

A `Response` that wraps `Success` as a `Result` of sorts.

### New structs!

`RequestIdentifier` contains `client_id` and `request_id`, as those go oftentime together.

### Comments

To explain some whats and whys, notably the purpose of the `in_flight` hashmap.

### Documentation

Have a look at the [new doc page](https://github.com/sozu-proxy/sozu/blob/0.14-refactor-command-server/doc/managing_workers.md) about the workflow of the Command Server.

## De-minify everything!

title: Update parser of header value to trim linear white space
body:
* According to the rfc 2616, section 2.2 and 4.2, the linear white space
  (lws) which are the horizontal tabulation ('\t') and the space (' ') MAY
  be trimmed.

  See rfc 2616, section 4.2:

  > The field-content does not include any leading or trailing LWS:
  > linear white space occurring before the first non-whitespace
  > character of the field-value or after the last non-whitespace
  > character of the field-value. Such leading or trailing LWS MAY be
  > removed without changing the semantics of the field value. Any LWS
  > that occurs between field-content MAY be replaced with a single SP
  > before interpreting the field value or forwarding the message
  > downstream.

Signed-off-by: Florentin Dubois <florentin.dubois@clever-cloud.com>

title: Refactoring of command execution
body:
This other pull request :

- #731

started small and turned into a whole refactoring of command execution. Debugging the ensuing chaos was difficult.

This PR here does only the refactoring of the command execution. Each order received in the loop of the `CommandServer`'s run function is pattern-matched and sent to specialized executing functions that return :

- `anyhow::Result` for error management, which in turn contains…
- a new enum called `OrderSuccess` that contains, depending on the case, relevant information about the order being successfull, as well as `CommandResponseData`.

title: Use already parsed certificate and chains in rustls hello method
error logging on getting saved_state from the config
body:
I realized Sōzu would start even if the `saved_state` provided in `config.toml` is wrong when doing

```
sozu --config config.toml start
```

To solve this I put the `saved_state_path()` method of `Config` inside its loading function, instead of within a spawned and unstoppable thread in `CommandServer::Start()` as it is now.

Add error management to it and it yields neat errors like this:

```
Error: Invalid configuration file.

Caused by:
    0: Invalid saved_state in the config. Check your config file
    1: could not get saved state path from config file input Some("./wrong_state_path.json")
    2: No such file or directory (os error 2)
```

title: Apply clippy suggestions using rust edition 2021
Fix the worker upgrade malfunction
body:
Investigating about this issue:

- #704 

reveals that the legacy code does check wether the worker we want to upgrade is alive and kicking… AFTER launching the spawn of the next one. This wrecks havoc, as examplified by this necessary fix:

- #725

Trying to upgrade a dead worker would *crash the entire proxy*.

This PR ensures that:

1. we check that the worker we want to upgrade is alive
2. if not, feedback is sent to the client
3. if it is alive, we go on with the upgrade process

title: switch to socket2
body: net2 has been deprecated for some time now

title: update to rustls 0.20
body:
A couple of caveats:
- for rustls, we now only pass the supported protocols to the configuration and log errors for others
- ~~when there is no match between configured ciphers and protocols, we now panic (which is far from ideal, but ...)~~

title: Replace the TODO "Why you should use Sōzu?"
Safeguard against thread panick scenario
body:
This is to resolve the behaviour pointed here:

- #704 

So I put a condition on an uncanny `unwrap()` so we don't give it a `None`

This fix should definitely be merged for safety, but should not close the issue, since the main process returns this info about a **dead worker*** :

```
➤ cargo run -- --config config.toml upgrade -w 1
initializing logger
upgrading worker 1
2021-October-27T17:03:49.483098Z 1635354229483098774 29290 MAIN INFO    Worker 1 is processing: sending configuration orders
Error: Command timeout. The proxy didn't send answer
```

title: Comprehensive timeout management
body:
To solve this issue:

- #723

We need:
- a proper management of timeout on **all** sozuctl operations, 
- to remove the `command_timeout!` macro that renders development difficult (weird typing mistakes)

This PR replaces the macro with:

```rust
fn read_channel_message_with_timeout(
    mut channel: Channel<CommandRequest, CommandResponse>,
    timeout: Duration,
) -> anyhow::Result<CommandResponse> {}
```

title: 0.14 socket connection error management
body:
As mentioned in

- #721 

We have a nasty `panic!` when trying to connect to a unix socket that isn't there.

```
thread 'main' panicked at 'could not connect to the command unix socket: Os { code: 111, kind: ConnectionRefused, message: "Connection refused" }', bin/src/ctl/mod.rs:37:43
```

This pull request fixes it with `anyhow` and its `Context` that make a much nicer (and more traceable) error management:

```
Error: could not connect to the command unix socket

Caused by:
    0: Could not create Channel from the given path
    1: Connection refused (os error 111)

```

title: fix socket removal on start
body:
As pointed out in this issue:

- #715 

A regression bug was introduced in commit 7c6f951 

Normal behaviour on start:

1. Sōzu wants to create a socket on the path configured with `command_socket`
2. Sōzu orders the deletion of a previously existing socket on the path (if any is there)
3. Sōzu creates a new one instead

The regression bug brings Sōzu to crash if no socket is present for deletion.

The fix consists in checking for the presence of a socket before deleting it.
